CONJUGATES: chickens (n plural) | chicken out (verb) | chickened out (verb past tense) | chickening out (verb present participle)
ETYMOLOGY: From Old English 'cicen', 'cycen' (a young fowl), diminutive of 'coc' (cock). Related to German 'Küken'.

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: noun: a word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun)
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A common domesticated fowl, Gallus gallus domesticus, raised for its meat and eggs.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 一种常见的家禽，通常为了肉和蛋而饲养。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The farmer keeps a large flock of chickens.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 那个农夫养了一大群鸡。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: noun: a word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun)
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: The meat of a chicken, used as food.
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: We're having roast chicken for dinner tonight.

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: noun: a word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun)
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A person who is afraid or cowardly.
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: Don't be such a chicken; just try it!
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 别当个胆小鬼，你就试试看！

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: adjective: a word or phrase naming an attribute, added to or grammatically related to a noun to modify or describe it
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: He was too chicken to ask her to dance.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 他太胆小了，不敢邀请她跳舞。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: phrasal verb: a verb combined with an adverb or a preposition, or sometimes both, to give a new meaning
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: To lose one's nerve; to decide not to do something because of fear.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 因害怕而退缩；临阵退缩。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: I almost went skydiving, but I chickened out at the last minute.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 我差点去跳伞了，但最后一刻退缩了。
